Conversion of Units

Author | Engr. Nico O. Aspra, ME, RMP

$$ \definecolor{colorA}{rgb}{0.25, 0.51, 0.43} %viridian \definecolor{colorB}{rgb}{0.89, 0.04, 0.36} %raspberry \definecolor{energy}{RGB}{114,0,172} \definecolor{freq}{RGB}{45,177,93} \definecolor{spin}{RGB}{251,0,29} \definecolor{signal}{RGB}{18,110,213} \definecolor{circle}{RGB}{217,86,16} \definecolor{average}{RGB}{203,23,206} \require{cancel} $$

The relationship between two quantities that have the same dimensions are interchangeable through conversion factors. For example, a rod that has a length of $5\un{m}$ can also be presented in feet [ft], since both meter and feet are units that represent the dimension of length, where $1 \,\text{m}=3.28\,\text{ft}$.

\[\begin{align*} \text{Length} &= 5\mathrm{\cancel{m}} \br{ \frac{3.28 \un{ft}}{1\mathrm{ \cancel{m}}} } \\ &= 16.4 \text{ ft} \tagans \end{align*}\] \[\Ncancel{2}{m}{5}{ft} \cdot \Dcancel{2}{m}{5}{m} \cdot \NDcancel{2}{m}{5}{m} \cdot \pd{x}{y}\]
